verses.text: In the second year of Joash son of Jehoahaz, king of Israel, Amaziah the son of Joash, king of Judah, began to reign.
verses.comment: The timeline links Judah and Israel, showing the interconnectedness of God’s people, and the continuity of leadership in both kingdoms.

verses.text: He was twenty-five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned twenty-nine years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Jehoaddin of Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The emphasis on his mother’s name shows the importance of lineage and family heritage within the royal line.

verses.text: He did what was right in the eyes of the LORD, yet not like David his father. He did according to all that Joash his father had done.
verses.comment: Amaziah obeys God but not perfectly, highlighting the need for true, wholehearted devotion—pointing toward the fulfillment in Christ who obeys fully.

verses.text: But the high places were not removed; the people continued to sacrifice and make offerings on the high places.
verses.comment: Worship outside the designated place foreshadows the call to unity in worship under one spiritual authority and one altar (see John 4:21-24).

verses.text: And as soon as the kingdom was firmly in his hand, he struck down his servants who had struck down the king his father.
verses.comment: Justice administered after a period of instability; parallels the necessity for order and mediation through divinely-appointed leadership.

verses.text: But he did not put to death the children of the murderers, according to what is written in the Book of the Law of Moses, where the LORD commanded, "Fathers shall not be put to death for the children, nor children be put to death for the fathers; but each one shall die for his own sin."
verses.comment: The text points to personal responsibility before God and the justice of God’s law, anticipating Christ’s personal bearing of mankind’s sins (Isaiah 53:5), yet with order and law maintained.

verses.text: He struck down 10,000 Edomites in the Valley of Salt and took Sela by storm, renaming it Joktheel, which is its name to this day.
verses.comment: Amaziah’s success over Edom builds on the earlier victories of David; the conquest of Sela shows the fulfillment of God’s promises to the house of David.

verses.text: Then Amaziah sent messengers to Jehoash son of Jehoahaz, son of Jehu, king of Israel, saying, "Come, let us look one another in the face."
verses.comment: Amaziah’s challenge displays self-confidence but also division among God’s people—foreshadowing the necessity of unity in the future (Eph 4:3).

verses.text: Jehoash king of Israel sent to Amaziah king of Judah, saying, "A thistle in Lebanon sent to a cedar in Lebanon, saying, ‘Give your daughter to my son in marriage’; but a wild beast of Lebanon passed by and trampled down the thistle."
verses.comment: This parable illustrates humility—reminding rulers that pride leads to downfall; spiritual pride can also destroy unity and order within the body of Christ.

verses.text: "You have indeed struck down Edom, and your heart has lifted you up. Be content with your glory, and stay at home. Why should you provoke trouble so that you fall, you and Judah with you?"
verses.comment: The warning against pride and unnecessary conflict teaches wisdom for leadership, and for humility in Christian living (James 4:6).

verses.text: But Amaziah would not listen. So Jehoash king of Israel went up, and he and Amaziah king of Judah faced each other at Beth-shemesh, which belongs to Judah.
verses.comment: Persistence in pride leads to strife and division; the consequences of disunity and unwillingness to heed wise counsel.

verses.text: Judah was defeated before Israel, and every man fled to his home.
verses.comment: Disunity brings downfall; prefigures the importance of unity in the true community of believers gathered under one spiritual authority.

verses.text: Jehoash king of Israel captured Amaziah king of Judah, the son of Joash, son of Ahaziah, at Beth-shemesh, and came to Jerusalem and broke down four hundred cubits of the wall of Jerusalem, from the Ephraim Gate to the Corner Gate.
verses.comment: The destruction of Jerusalem’s wall symbolizes vulnerability due to lack of unity and faithfulness; only through one Shepherd is Jerusalem secure.

verses.text: And he took all the gold and silver and all the vessels found in the house of the LORD and in the treasuries of the king’s palace, plus hostages, and returned to Samaria.
verses.comment: The loss of temple treasures recalls later exiles; points to the necessity for safeguarding the sacred, especially the true worship and treasures of faith.

verses.text: Now the rest of the acts of Jehoash, what he did and his might, and how he fought with Amaziah king of Judah, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel?
verses.comment: Reference to historical records confirms the scriptural account; points out the thoroughness and reliability of scriptural history.

verses.text: So Jehoash slept with his fathers and was buried in Samaria with the kings of Israel, and Jeroboam his son reigned in his place.
verses.comment: The passing of the kingdom, father to son, affirms hereditary succession and the continuity of divine promises through generations.

verses.text: Amaziah son of Joash, king of Judah, lived fifteen years after the death of Jehoash son of Jehoahaz, king of Israel.
verses.comment: Amaziah’s extended reign, even after defeat, shows that God’s mercy may endure despite judgment.

verses.text: Now the rest of the acts of Amaziah, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah?
verses.comment: Again, scriptural records reinforce the faithfulness of God’s Word and the factual nature of Biblical history.

verses.text: They made a conspiracy against him in Jerusalem, and he fled to Lachish. But they sent after him to Lachish and killed him there.
verses.comment: The repetition of conspiracy and assassination in Judah’s history shows the consequences of sin and faithless leadership; highlights the need of a faithful redeemer King.

verses.text: They brought him on horses, and he was buried in Jerusalem with his fathers in the city of David.
verses.comment: Burial in the city of David connects Amaziah with the promised lineage, maintaining the hope for the future messianic King.

verses.text: All the people of Judah took Azariah, who was sixteen years old, and made him king in place of his father Amaziah.
verses.comment: Popular acclamation of Azariah hints at both hereditary and communal guidance in choosing leadership, blending spiritual and temporal authority.

verses.text: He rebuilt Elath and restored it to Judah, after the king slept with his fathers.
verses.comment: Restoration of Elath represents recovering what was lost through faithfulness, a theme pointing toward spiritual restoration for the faithful.

verses.text: In the fifteenth year of Amaziah the son of Joash king of Judah, Jeroboam son of Joash king of Israel began to reign in Samaria, and he reigned forty-one years.
verses.comment: A long reign for Jeroboam II is noted, setting the stage for Israel’s growth and subsequent judgment.

verses.text: He did what was evil in the eyes of the LORD. He did not turn away from all the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat, which he made Israel to sin.
verses.comment: Jeroboam II’s evil ways reinforce the destructive pattern begun by his ancestor, indicating the danger of persistent false worship and doctrine.

verses.text: He restored the border of Israel from Lebo-hamath as far as the Sea of the Arabah, according to the word of the LORD, the God of Israel, which He spoke through His servant Jonah son of Amittai, the prophet, from Gath-hepher.
verses.comment: Here Jonah is mentioned as a prophet; God’s faithfulness in keeping His word is seen even when leaders are unfaithful. The role of the prophet as spokesperson for God’s authority is emphasized.

verses.text: For the LORD saw that the affliction of Israel was very bitter, there was no helper for Israel, neither bond nor free.
verses.comment: God’s compassion shines through—even in judgment—demonstrating a type of Christ who takes pity and comes as our true Helper (John 14:16).

verses.text: Yet the LORD did not say that He would blot out the name of Israel from under heaven, so He delivered them by the hand of Jeroboam son of Joash.
verses.comment: Despite Israel’s sins, God’s irrevocable promises remain—prefiguring His faithfulness to the new covenant people upheld through authoritative teaching and apostolic succession.

verses.text: Now the rest of the acts of Jeroboam and all that he did, and his might—how he fought and how he recovered Damascus and Hamath for Israel—are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel?
verses.comment: Recovered lands signify restoration, but a warning remains about relying on temporal power rather than spiritual fidelity and unity.

verses.text: So Jeroboam slept with his fathers, the kings of Israel; and Zechariah his son reigned in his place.
verses.comment: This verse closes the chapter with continued succession, emphasizing the enduring significance of family, tradition, and continuity—prefiguring the safeguarding of truth through ordered succession in God’s people.
